ygData.subject: Re: Is it possible to set mole fractions with variables???

Thank you very much Gokul. This is exactly what I was looking for. I
alrea=
dy implemented it and it's working. Thanks again. Best regards,
Peter


---=
 In cantera@yahoogroups.com, P Gokulakrishnan <pgokulak@...> wrote:
>
>
> P=
eter:
>
> You can set the variables as strings in the following format in
p=
ython:
>
>
gas.set(T=3D900.0,P=3D1.0e5,X=3D'CH4:'+str(mole_CH4)+',O2:'+str(=
mole_O2)+',N2:\
'+str(mole_N2)+'')
>
> -Gokul-
>
> Peter Perez plpd00@... w=
rote: Thanks Anatoli and Dave for your kind
reply. What I meant (not sure
>=
 what a "functor" is) is to be able to set the mole fractions by using
> va=
riables instead of the string in the set command. For example, I
> would li=
ke to do something like this:
>
> mole_CH4 =3D 1.0
> mole_O2 =3D 1/phi*(1+y=
/4.0)) # phi and y are computed in my code.
> mole_N2 =3D (1/phi*(1+y/4.0)*=
(Xn2/Xo2)) # Xn2, Xo2 are mole fractions.
>
> Then set the mole fractions w=
ith something like this:
> gas.set(T=3D900.0,P=3D1.0e5,X=3D'CH4:mole_CH4,O2=
:mole_O2,N2:mole_N2')
>
> Right now, I just compute the new stoichiometry (=
according to my phi)
> and then modify the value in the set command. This i=
s not a big deal,
> but it takes some time when you want to do the calculat=
ion for many
> conditions. Anatoli's approach is a very good idea. However,=
 it still
> requires the mole fractions to be given as strings, which do no=
t
> support arithmetic operations. Thank you both again for your interest
>=
 and help. Best Regards, Peter
>
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "avmokho=
v" avmokhov@ wrote:
> >
> > Hi Peter,
> > For me it is also not clear what =
do you want to do. Do you mean to
> > add a function to Cantera, which retu=
rns a calculated composition
> > based on phi such as
> > string mixture_co=
mposition(const string& fuel, const string&
> > Oxidizer, double phi) ?
> >=

> > It is quite easy to implement and I use this function in my
> > calcul=
ations. Than you can do something like that
> >
> > double T =3D 300;
> > d=
ouble P =3D 1.0e5;
> > string fuel =3D "CH4:0.8,H2:0.2";
> > string oxidize=
r =3D "O2:0.2,N2:0.8";
> > double phi =3D 1.0;
> > gas.set(T, P, mixture_co=
mposition(fuel, oxidizer, phi));
> >
> > Best regards, Anatoli
> >
> > --- =

on't understand what you want to do - what are the data types

things like "CH4:m ole"? I infer that you want to give functors,

t

ive something like:
